Subject:
Re: E
Energy Business Model Development

You might find this article interesting. As mentioned in the article, last week was another historic week in the energy business, where the private equity firm of Apollo acquired The Unical Petroleum Corporation, in the most recent in a series of U.S. companies who’ve been bought by foreign entities. With foreign financial firms having acquired Blythe & Blythe Energy, CITGO, Pacific Gas & Electric, Southwestern Bell, Texas Utilities, among others, it is rather apparent that while the American energy market remains the largest, there are better opportunities elsewhere. As an energy venture capital firm focused on developing LNG, Biomass, Oil & Gas projects and related ventures

Hi Bobby,                      Bonny is fine to call to board immediately. However, the berthing congestion is currently at Monrovia. <Email 4>:
Hi Isaac,                       We have approved the documents. Could you send us your bank account details so that we can make the payments

They get a reply to only the last email. There are reasons why they could be having difficulty in getting through to their target. This happens frequently when it comes to end-user targets in emerging markets.
I always leave two days in my inbox to send another follow up email after the first one is sent and then at the end of the day send another one. This seems to work better than the more traditional 3-day/3-email rule.

While we see high open rates, it’s possible that the real target isn’t looking for the product at this time and may not have read the email. You don’t really know for sure unless you get a reply from the target

<Email 4>:
 On Mon, May 20, 2019 at 05:54 PM,  wrote:

* Why the captain and other crew leave the bridge, walk away from the wheel, and forget where the wheel is? Is this typical, or is it just human nature?

 It is not typical. Any crew that is leaving the bridge for more than a few minutes will usually assign a watchkeeper and/or specify exactly where the wheel is. If the owner insists on an automatic pilot watchkeeper, it is up to the captain to comply. But that would not be my recommendation.

* If the vessel is in or near a harbor or channel where there are many vessels and navigating is a challenge, why do the ships leave the bridge and let the ship just drift out of control? Would not knowing exactly where the wheel is be a problem? I am talking about not having a person at the helm ready

<Email 4>:
 On Mon, May 20, 2019 at 05:54 PM,  wrote:

* Why the captain and other crew leave the bridge, walk away from the wheel, and forget where the wheel is? Is this typical, or is it just human nature?

 It is not typical. Any crew that is leaving the bridge for more than a few minutes will usually assign a watchkeeper and/or specify exactly where the wheel is. If the owner insists on an automatic pilot watchkeeper, it is up to the captain to comply. But that would not be my recommendation.

* If the vessel is in or near a harbor or channel where there are many vessels and navigating is a challenge, why do the ships leave the bridge and let the ship just drift out of control? Would not knowing exactly where the wheel is be a problem? I am talking about not having a person at the helm ready
